Issues.Title: Window.open(path, '_parent'); redirects to base route.
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/router` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 5 I believe this was working at some point in Angular5. I upgraded two major versions (6 and 7) and have noticed this is no longer functioning. This is causing issues within our application. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... After using `window.open(path, '_parent');` my page seems to temporarily load my my component/route and then immediately reboots the entire application. (Not sure if this is a browser back or what) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/TheeRFG/ng-broken-routing 1. `ng serve` 2. Click the link to "Route B!" 3. Watch the application temporarily load "route-b works!" before rebootstrapping and starting back at "I am root!" ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

**Anything else relevant?** In my bigger application where I first noticed this issue, even though my root path is linked to a component my page actually sits at ```
``` and subsequent initial navigations fail. Navigations _after_ this first failed navigation work and resolve, but this is not an ideal user experience. I realize there are better routing solutions available to Angular, but because of the legacy nature of a large portion of our application and its use of frames, this is the only way for our application to tell the parent windows they need to navigate.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support checkNoChanges on embedded views
Issues.Body:
Before this fix our ViewRef implementation assumed that checkNoChanges can be
only called on component views. In reality checkNoChanges can be also called on
embedded views (ex.: when an embedded view is attached to ApplicationRef).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): support checkNoChanges on embedded views" (#28644)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): compile pipe in context of ternary operator
Issues.Body:
Previously, it wasn't possible to compile template that contains pipe in context of ternary operator `{{ 1 ? 2 : 0 | myPipe }}` due to the error `Error: Illegal state: Pipes should have been converted into functions. Pipe: async`. See also https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/28587#issuecomment-461486458

This PR fixes a typo in expression parser so that pipes are correctly converted into functions.

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): allow non-unique #localRefs to be defined in a template
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change in Ivy we had strict check that disabled non-unique #localRefs usage within a given template. While this limitation was technically present in View Engine, in many cases View Engine neglected this restriction and as a result, some apps relied on a fact that multiple non-unique #localRefs can be defined and utilized to query elements via `@ViewChild(ren)` and `@ContentChild(ren)`. In order to provide better compatibility with View Engine, this commit removes existing restriction.

As a part of this commit, are few tests were added to verify VE and Ivy compatibility in most common use-cases where multiple non-unique #localRefs were used.

Issues.Title: 3rd party packages can cause console.log() to trigger change detection
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core. ### Is this a regression? No. ### Description If a 3rd party library adds behavior to the `console.log()` function, `zone.js` will erroneously trigger change detection. If the `console.log()` statement is in a function bound to the view model, change detection can recursively run. An easy way to prevent the problem would be to wrap the `console.log` statement to run outside of angular. However, this is very unwieldy and not-obvious to a developer adding `console.log` statements to debug their program (aka me). I recognize that this likely could be considered an issue with the 3rd party package. However, I'm not entirely certain that there is anything that _can_ be done from that package, as it is meant to be a generic package used in a variety of projects, and not just Angular projects. The 3rd party package, in this case, is [Sentry](https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-javascript), which overwrites the `console.log` function in order to record breadcrumbs for error logging. I'm opening an issue both here and against Sentry's repo, because I'm very uncertain which project can/should ultimately fix this issue. Edit: https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-javascript/issues/1883 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Reproduction repo that uses [Sentry](https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-javascript) to reproduce the problem: https://github.com/ibedard16/sentry-recursion-demo Instructions to reproduce are in the [readme](https://github.com/ibedard16/sentry-recursion-demo#the-demo). ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: build: fix rollup config tslint rule not working on windows
Issues.Body:
The `rollupConfigRule` currently does not work on Windows
because it accidentally fails looking for the `rollup.config.js` files.

This is because the tslint rule compares the current `ts.SourceFile`
file path with the `process.cwd()` path. This is problematic because
TypeScript by default only returns posix-paths, and the path comparisons
are therefore always invalid. In order to properly compare the two paths,
we need to normalize the TypeScript source file path.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: fix rollup config tslint rule not working on windows" (#28646)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support schemas at runtime
Issues.Body:
Accounts for schemas in when validating properties in Ivy.

This PR resolves FW-819.

A couple of notes:
* I had to rework the test slightly, in order to have it fail when we expect it to. The one in master is passing since Ivy's validation runs during the update phase, rather than creation.
* I had to deviate from the design in FW-819 and not add an `enableSchema` instruction, because the schema is part of the `NgModule` scope, however the scope is only assigned to a component once all of the module's declarations have been resolved and some of them can be async. Instead, I opted to have the `schemas` on the component definition.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): support schemas at runtime" (#28637)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): allow directive inheritance in strict mode
Issues.Body:
For TypeScript compilation units that have the "strictFunctionTypes"
option enabled, an error would be produced for Ivy's definition fields
in declaration files in the case of inheritance across directives or
pipes.

This change loosens the definition types to allow for subtypes of the
defined type where necessary.

A test package that has the "strict" option enabled verifies that we
won't regress in environments where strict type checking is enabled.

Fixes #28079

Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): no longer re-export external symbols by default
Issues.Body:
**[NOTICE]**: Commit message is based on the fact that #28594 will be merged before this PR.

Blocked on #28594.

---

With #28594 we refactored the `@angular/compiler` API slightly to allow
opting out from external symbol re-exports which are enabled by default.

Since symbol re-exports only benefit projects which have a very strict
dependency enforcement, external symbols should not be re-exported
by default as this could grow the size of factory files and cause unexpected
behavior with Angular's AOT symbol resolving (e.g. see: #25644).

Additionally "ngtsc" also does not provide any way of using external symbol
re-exports, so this means that NGC partially matches the behavior of "ngtsc"
then (unless explicitly opted-out).

Internally at Google, symbol re-exports need to be still enabled since Google
has a very strict dependency enforcement (even of produced JavaScript output),
so the `ng_module` Bazel rule will enable the symbol re-exports by default when
running within Blaze.

Fixes #25644.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(compiler-cli): no longer re-export external symbols by default" (#28633)

Issues.Title: fix(router): add warning for the relative route without the relativeT‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶o property

Method 'validateCommands' moved to the class methods for use the context console for warnings.

Fixes #26027

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
When using `router.navigate(‚Ä¶)` with relative _url_ and without `relativeTo` property, angular does not show any warnings and behave in a confusing manner.

Issue Number: #26027


## What is the new behavior?
When You are using `router.navigate(‚Ä¶)` with relative _url_  and without setting `relativeTo` property, angular shows warning message in the console: `WARNING: using relative route without the 'relativeTo' property`

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


## Other information
I have chosen `validateCommands` for relative routing checks cuz of logical consistency.
Also, method `navigateByUrl` do not apply relative URLs so there no need to pass such checks there.

Issues.Title: Angular 7.2.4 - Unmet Peer Dependancy
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [X ] update ``` ### Is this a regression? Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description Okay, As usual im notified on angular updates, I went to run the ng update command as usual to be correctly notified of the 7.2.4 updates (going from 7.2.3) After installing im notified of peer dependancies missing ** > npm ERR! peer dep missing: ajv@^6.9.1, required by ajv-keywords@3.4.0 ** ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - ng new - Let node install - See error: ajv-keywords@3.4.0 requires a peer of ajv@^6.9.1 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself. ## üî• Exception or Error 

ajv-keywords@3.4.0 requires a peer of ajv@^6.9.1 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.
## üåç Your Environment 

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.13.1
@angular-devkit/core         7.3.1
@angular-devkit/schematics   7.3.1
@schematics/angular          7.3.1
@schematics/update           0.13.1
rxjs                         6.3.3
typescript                   3.2.4
**Anything else relevant?** Performing npm ls --depth 0 will identify the issues ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ UNMET PEER DEPENDENCY @angular/common@7.2.4 ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ UNMET PEER DEPENDENCY @angular/core@7.2.4 If this was an expected dependancy I should think it would be put in dev dependancies instead of installing it after upgrading? It seems odd that out of the box this doesn't come installed. Hopefully this is enough info to track down.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular 7.2.4 - Unmet Peer Dependancy" (#13649)

Issues.Title: Add support for generating files on secondary entry points (sub packages)
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Creating a [secondary entry point](https://github.com/ng-packagr/ng-packagr/blob/master/docs/secondary-entrypoints.md), like testing, by hand isn't an issue on its own, but using the CLI for generating files for it, is. Whenever I try to generate a file for it, I need to be on the folder or write something like `ng g c ../../testing/src/lib/my-comp --project my-lib`.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I've imagined adding a `--project` flag to `ng generate library` to generate a secondary entry point:
`ng g lib testing --project my-lib`

The structure would be something like below:
```
my-lib
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src
|   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ lib
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ testing
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src
    |   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib
    |   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ public_api.ts
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json
```

The command would also add a property, like `entries`, on _angular.json_ library configuration, holding the secondary entry point path. We would need this property for when generating other files, like the following:
`ng g c my-comp --project my-lib/testing`

### Describe alternatives you've considered
We could have a new generation schematic for secondary entry points or a property to add the reference path on _angular.json_ manually.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add support for generating files on secondary entry points (sub packages)" (#13633)

Issues.Title: Wrong SockJS Host validation with Reverse Proxy
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

Angular CLI version : 7.2.3

### Command (mark with an `x`)

```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Is this a regression?

I don't know

### Description

When using "ng serve" behind a reverse proxy on a sub-path, the SockJS Server throws 400 errors because it fails to validate the Host/Origin header.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

I want to have my application served on my workstation at `http://dev.local/common-demo`

1. Create a new Angular CLI project
2. Configure the `serve` task in `angular.json` with
```json
            "host": "localhost",
            "port": 9038,
            "publicHost": "dev.local/common-demo/sockjs-node",
            "baseHref": "/common-demo/",
            "servePath": "/"
```
3. Configure you workstation reverse proxy with (here Apache is used)
```
ProxyPass /common-demo http://localhost:9038
ProxyPassReverse /common-demo http://localhost:9038
```

## üî• Exception or Error

Chrome console shows :

```
WebSocket connection to 'ws://dev.local/common-demo/sockjs-node/287/kbmqffv3/websocket' failed: Error during WebSocket handshake: Unexpected response code: 400

Invalid Host/Origin header

[WDS] Disconnected!
```

**Notes**

If I set `disableHostCheck` to `true`, it works, but I don't want to.

If I set `publicHost` to `dev.local` the app tries to connect to `ws://dev.local/sockjs-node` which is not valid as it ignores the `baseHref`.

The `servePath` needs to be `/` as the app is served at the root of `localhost:9038` (by default `servePath` inherits from `baseHref` but the sub-path is handled by the Reverse Proxy in my setup).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Wrong SockJS Host validation with Reverse Proxy" (#13627)

### Description
When setting "es5BrowserSupport": true in angular.json I get errors in IE 11 because it does not recognize .includes()
`TypeError: Object doesn't support property or method 'includes'`

This issue below gave the original workaround, perhaps now that it is in a conditional polyfill we can add it by default.
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/4128

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add the following polyfill to the Conditional ES5 Browser Polyfill so that .includes() works with IE 11
`import 'core-js/es7/array';`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I can keep `import 'core-js/es7/array';` in the main polyfill file, but it is not needed by other browsers

Issues.Title: matInput doesn't reflect type if set via component
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
In case of `matInput`, if type is set as `number` using property binding, it's type should be fetched as number in component and not string. e.g. 
```
<matInput [type]="typePropetyNameInComponent">

typePropetyNameInComponent: string = "number"; 
```

doesn't work as expected while type="number" does.

#### What is the current behavior?
When type is set as `number` using property binding, it reflects the changes in template in terms of validation, but when value is fetched in component, it's type is `string` instead of `number`. The same thing works perfectly when type is directly set in template like `type="number"`

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Here's the example of this behavior: https://stackblitz.com/edit/example-angular-material-reactive-form-vxs2mu

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular: 7.0.0
Material: 7.0.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "matInput doesn't reflect type if set via component" (#15141)

Issues.Title: Allow palettes to specify a separate hue for uncontained text
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

There is a lot of emphasis on making sure that you choose accessible text colors to ensure readability when your palette color is used in the background but there is no such concern when your palette color itself is used as the text color on a neutral background. This is exacerbated by the fact that @angular/material components will implicitly use the default hue of the palette when selecting this text color - for example in `_form-field_theme.scss`:

  ```$focused-label-color: mat-color($primary);```

it's very hard to pick a palette whose primary is effective both as a strong background color and as a strong text color for small text on a neutral background _and_ conforms to any existing brand guidelines.

One way to fix this would be to extend `mat-palette` with a fourth argument, `$text`. For compatibility it could default to `$default` if not specified, but this would allow you to use a much darker hue on form field labels and so on without making primary backgrounds darker everywhere else.

You can quite easily see the accessibility issues with the current system with some of the prepackaged themes. For instance setting the theme to `purple-green` on https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/examples gives a contrast ratio of 2.09 for the form field inputs.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

Improves accessibility

#### Is there anything else we should know?

No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow palettes to specify a separate hue for uncontained text" (#15148)

Issues.Title: Bug: cannot drop in connected cdkDropList inside element that has a ngIf
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

If a cdkDropList is inside an html element that has a ngIf, when the ngIf is at true state, you can drop elements inside the drop list if it is correctly connected to the origin list.

#### What is the current behavior?

You can't.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material-drag-and-drop-bug).

As you can see, there are event handlers in cdk-drag-drop-connected-sorting-example so that the second-component's drop list container is visible only when you are dragging an element.
If you drag an element from the first list, you can't drop it in the second one, but if you remove the ngIf in second-component, you will be able to. There is no wiring for drop events, however you can see if you can drop (or not) as the list splits (or not) to leave space for the new element.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

I am running Angular 7.2.2, CDK 7.3.0, TypeScript 3.2.4, I have reproduced the issue on Firefox 65 and Chrome 71 on Ubuntu 18.04.1.

#### Is there anything else we should know?

This issue seems related to #13998, as you can see, I was careful to use string ids like said.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Bug: cannot drop in connected cdkDropList inside element that has a ngIf" (#15139)
